text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm and welcome to our cooking
grass-fed beef series alright today
we're doing a top round London broil
using this delicious grass-fed beef this
beef came from Steve normanton from
normanton Farms in New Hampshire which
we are going to first safely defrost so
when you give frozen meat like this very
important you have to slowly defrost it
so what I like to do is get a big bowl
some paper towel put the roast right on
top and we're just going to put that in
the fridge for two days it's going to
take about 48 hours to thaw you want to
thought nice and slowly
none of this microwaving thawing running
under water you know there are shortcut
methods but not recommended so what you
see here is about a three and a half
pound piece of top round once it's been
safely thawed we are going to cut this
in half so I'm going to set it up on its
side because I'm going to get two
recipes out of this and we're going to
make one slice down directly through the
center and that's going to give us two
thick pieces those are about two inches
thick what we're going to do is we're
going to take the two-thirds of the part
that doesn't have any connective tissue
and we're going to make what's called a
London broil that bottom part where you
see that extra kind of connective tissue
fat so you see that we're going to trim
that right off and the knife will go
right between those muscles so you're
really easy to trim all right you just
kind of feel with your fingers where
that muscles separating all right let's
try with the other piece so you see that
I can kind of push my finger right in
there and it's just there's like a
natural separation so what that gave us
is two pieces of top round that are
commonly referred to as London broil
just means a thick top round steak
boneless of course and then I have about
a pound and a half of top round stew
meat that I'm going to make a nice meat
sauce out of so onto the London broil
I'm going to make a really simple
balsamic marinade balsamic vinegar olive
oil some nice fresh sliced garlic and of
course all these amounts are on the site
all right and a lot of black pepper I'm
also going to put in some dried Italian
herbs all right give that a good mix
we're going to dip the steaks in the
marinade make sure it's coated on both
sides and then with the tip of the fork
we're going to kind of puncture this and
poke it so that the marinade really can
get in there
so you can want to poke that on both
sides contrary to popular belief
marinating does not tenderize meat and
I'm talking about acidic marinades
vinegar marinades alright it flavors it
it doesn't tenderize it unless you have
some kind of yogurt or dairy product in
there and then we're going to wrap this
in plastic and refrigerate it marinate
it overnight now you can go less you can
go for six hours if you have to but I
think it's better overnight so we're
going to cover that put it back in the
fridge then when we're ready to cook all
right we're going to preheat our broiler
on high I'm going to take a sheet pan
with some foil in a little just baking
rack and that's going to lift the meat
up off the pan and it Broyles a little
better so I'm going to put one of those
steaks down I'm going to do one at a
time in fact if you want since you get
two steaks out of that roast you can do
one with one marinade one with another
really versatile salt and pepper very
well both sides so I have my broiler set
on high and I'm going to broil this
about 8 inches from the heat for
approximately 6 7 minutes per side for
this piece this shape this size it
really will vary so you're going to have
to go not by the times I'm giving you
but by temperature all right very
important you don't overcook grass-fed
beef because it is very low fat one of
the huge advantages of eating grass-fed
beef is the low fat content so you got
to cook in a little ringer so what I'm
shooting for here I took it out when it
was 120 and that's a little on the rare
side for what you normally see for
medium-rare but I'm going to cover this
with foil for 10 minutes and that went
up another 5 degrees so it was like 125
when it was finished after its rested
you simply cut it across the grain so
you look for the way the grain of the
meats running so I found that and you
cut directly across that nice thin
strips you can see how juicy and tender
and medium-rare that is so nice so for
me the keys to a delicious top round
London broil style and nice marinade
cooking it medium-rare letting it rest
thoroughly and then slicing thin across
the grain you serve that with those
natural juice
is an incredibly delicious flavorful and
really easy way to cook grass-fed at top
round and if you don't like medium-rare
meat and you don't want to do the London
broil method I'm going to show you what
to do with those pieces we trimmed off
you can also use top round to make a
great meat sauce so stay tuned for that
video so I hope you give this a try I
hope you start cooking with grass-fed
beef it's a great extremely healthy
product all the ingredients for this
particular recipe are on the site and as
always enjoy
